text: I started trading options back in 2007 while I was in high school and it's the primary way that I built my original layer of wealth the goal of this videoos to walk you through how I trade options the idea is to kind of pull together all these different concepts into one place to give you some ideas because what I do doesn't really matter to you but hopefully you can gain some different ideas Inspirations from some of the things that I do and maybe bake it into your process have better results going forward so you'll notice on the left hand side we have some guiding Concepts called what I pursue right hand side gets a little deeper into my actual approach let's start on the left- hand side with the guiding Concepts process driven what does this mean well when I first started trading the vast majority of what I did really had me focusing on the outcome of a single trade that sounds kind of important doesn't it why wouldn't I emphasize the outcome of a single trade well it's because I noticed that there was a propensity for me to start doing a lot of things that disagreed with my plan trying to salvage the individual trade and then I started noticing that I would deviate from the plan way more frequently trying to salvage other trades then I noticed that essentially I wasn't doing anything related to the plan and I had nothing

text: of things that disagreed with my plan trying to salvage the individual trade and then I started noticing that I would deviate from the plan way more frequently trying to salvage other trades then I noticed that essentially I wasn't doing anything related to the plan and I had nothing to lean on to figure out what I was doing wrong because I was just doing whatever I wanted so the idea behind process driven is that my goal is to create something that's repeatable for the long run one of the biggest mistakes I made as a early Trader and I imagine same with a lot of other people people is I had the idea that I was going to turn my 5,000 account 33,000 account 115,000 account into my future wealth the reality is that's not going to happen for the vast majority of people it's going to take a lot of saving more money making more money by achieving better jobs while you're saving more and in third lever you can pull is getting better at trading so in this scenario by focusing on the individual trade outcomes I'm sitting here trying to put the cart in front of the horse thinking well if I can just get a bunch of money really fast on these trades I'll be set and it's a really naive perspective it doesn't bear out so the main thing I remind myself is that everything I do feeds a process that I

text: front of the horse thinking well if I can just get a bunch of money really fast on these trades I'll be set and it's a really naive perspective it doesn't bear out so the main thing I remind myself is that everything I do feeds a process that I should be able to execute not over the next week month year 5 years 10 years literally over several decades is the idea and that leans to what you see down here number five is robustness what I do needs to make sense not just today not just in the current market environment but how can I create an approach that allows me to stay up to dat with what the Market's doing because for example if we take a look at a chart and we go back let's check out SPX and then let's go back like 5 years you'll notice that SPX over the last 5 years has done different things it had this really steep decline during covid then stimulus checks came out started skyrocketing back up came back down went sideways for a little bit and then it started grinding back up so if you develop an approach that does well here and only here here it lacks robustness it means that you don't have the skill set to trade this kind of environment or this kind of environment or maybe a slower drift up and the idea is to be able to trade all of

text: at a hypothetical scenario over 30 years where we start with 25,000 and we save 115,000 per month at 15 return versus 16 return 1 variance at the end of that leads to a 2.2 million variance I care about the difference between 15 and 16 because I care about 2.2 million over that time frame the tricky part is if you look at this for the first 16 years it's not much of a difference you can't really see what's going on here but that's the nature of compounding returns they take time to display themselves but then notice once you get over here towards year 30 look at the gap between these as it's opening up this just becomes parabolic from there I care about that 1 that 1 difference is a lot of money I care about that so should you the last thing here is skeptical optimism in the finance world you notice that there's no shortage of complete and utter but I still remain open to information just about all of it there is a heavy screening process that data goes through as I'm receiving it I think it's done me really well remaining very open to new data but being highly skeptical in how I analyze it see how quantifiable it is see how rigorous the origin of the thesis is those Details Matter a lot but you don't want to get too close-minded in my opinion because markets change and as soon as

text: open to new data but being highly skeptical in how I analyze it see how quantifiable it is see how rigorous the origin of the thesis is those Details Matter a lot but you don't want to get too close-minded in my opinion because markets change and as soon as you get to the point where you don't want to change anything you're going to start falling behind all right let's talk about the approach I take a very top- down approach I start with the economy then I'll look at the market the indices sectors sub sectors I want to understand from a broad picture how things are moving why what are the primary themes so right now the primary themes are still high inflation it's getting fairly persistent the economy is still fairly strong but slowing in some instances and we're seeing things like AI still being very interesting although it's now just starting to WAN a little bit in this next earning cycle so there's a lot of interesting things that you can kind of devise just from that so based on these two inputs I'm going to come up with the disposition how do I feel about things what do I think makes sense for the portfolio that I want to construct based on this information then I'm going to build a portfolio around it and make sure that each individual position in the portfolio supports this disposition collectively so even though for example let's say

text: about things what do I think makes sense for the portfolio that I want to construct based on this information then I'm going to build a portfolio around it and make sure that each individual position in the portfolio supports this disposition collectively so even though for example let's say that I'm bullish in Tech does that mean that everything I have in the portfolio is bullish Tech no because there's other things at play and I want to make sure I integrate that into what I'm doing this is really important for options Traders number two this idea that profit mechanisms come first then we fit a strategy all this means is I'm not going to look at the market and say hey where can I put on a vertical spread where can I put on a ratio diagonal I don't really care so much about what structure or strategy I'm using what I care about is what opportunity am I trying to capture and then what strategy fits it the best so the cliffnotes version of this is if I want to trade something bullish The Profit mechanism is bullish something going up in value that's what matters then if I choose to buy a call sell a put that's just a expression of what fits the portfolio best they both make money in the same scenario how much they make how much risk they have that's the difference you have to focus on the profit mechanism first

text: then if I choose to buy a call sell a put that's just a expression of what fits the portfolio best they both make money in the same scenario how much they make how much risk they have that's the difference you have to focus on the profit mechanism first the structure and the strategy just give us ideas on how to capture it so how to derivatives specifically options fit into my life well I use both long and short premium strategies not wedded to either or I actually think they both have a use case so I don't limit myself to being an Theta ganger or somebody that's just trying to buy YOLO options I do everything I generally use undefined risk structures so I'm not spreading things off with verticals more often than not and I simply manage the risk of the positions so rather than putting on a vertical spread and then just letting it go I might sell a put or buy a call and then if it's not doing what I want I'll manage the trade in the middle as compared to just letting it go what I'm trying to do here is reduce the friction of what I'm putting on when I'm trading directionally with options I'm looking for leverage the other reason why I like options is because it gives me exposure to specific things like volatility that you can't really isolate as well with an equity itself I use all different

text: the friction of what I'm putting on when I'm trading directionally with options I'm looking for leverage the other reason why I like options is because it gives me exposure to specific things like volatility that you can't really isolate as well with an equity itself I use all different time frames everything from zero days out to 180 is kind of the majority of what I do I have stuff that goes out past a year it's a little bit of everything and it depends a lot on what the market is doing again I'm agnostic to time frame what I care most about is the profit mechanism first and foremost and then the time frames I'm using are just designed to help me capture the profit mechanism so I don't go into this thinking oh I only want to trade you know 90day options I I don't really care I don't really care if it's 90-day options what I care about is how do I best capture this profit mechanism next thing is for directional trades I have a bullish tendency in me and it's because markets quantitatively display bullish drift so I don't look to stand in front of that um unless there's a really good reason so I typically am looking for Trend momentum drift style directional plays I like breakouts breakdowns like I showed you in that rut position and then these are the strategies that I use for bullish and bearish directional trades I
